item.description: Speakers 1.35 billion native speakers across all of its varieties Mandarin Chinese is the official language of China, Singapore, and Taiwan Cantonese is the official language of Hong Kong and Macau Significant number of Chinese speakers abroad, such as in the Chinatowns in New York City and San Francisco.
Notes here based on Peace Corps China Lesson 3. Pointing to something and naming it. 是 shì is “to be”. It is normally followed by a noun which defines the topic or subject.
Intro [[About the Chinese Language]] [[What Do You Call Chinese]]? [[Should You Learn Traditional Characters or Simplified Characters]]? [[How to Input Chinese on a Computer]] Script and Sound

Most native Chinese speakers are able to write in only one of the two systems, though they can usually read both it is easier for people who learn Traditional to read both sets Simplified characters are less intimidating for beginners “if you like the traditional meanings and history of the charcters, learn traditional” simplified characters are more commonly used in mainland China and the business world traditional Chinese characters are more common in Hong Kong, Macau, and Taiwan.
In short, it depends. When I say “Chinese” or “Mandarin Chinese”, I’m referring to the modern, standardized form of Mandarin Chinese; the same one that’s used in the United Nations.
